content.text: There are 200 sheets of iron in the core of the transformer. The thickness of the core is \(50 \text{mm}\)
Calculate the average thickness of **one** sheet of iron
The density of the iron in the core is \(7.65 \text{g} /\text{cm}^3\). The mass of the core is \(1377 \text{g}\)
Calculate the volume of the core
State the name of a device used to measure mass
Fig. 1.1 shows the core of a transformer. It is made from thin sheets of iron
Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)
when the time is 5.0 s
when the car is moving with a constant speed
Determine the speed of the car using information from Fig. 2.1:
Describe how the speed of the car changes between 30.0 s and 60.0 s
Determine the distance travelled by the car between 10.0 s and 30.0 s
distance travelled = .........m
The total distance travelled by the car in the last 30.0 s is 226 m
Calculate the average speed of the car in the last 30.0 s
average speed = .........m/s
Fig. 2.1 shows how the speed of a car varies between 0 and 60.0 s
The weight of the beam is \(150\mathrm{N}\). This acts at a distance of \(1.8\mathrm{m}\) from the pivot as shown in Fig. 3.1
Calculate the moment of the weight of the beam about the pivot
Include the correct unit in your answer
moment of weight of beam = .........unit .........
When the weight \(W\) of the heavy weight acts at a distance of \(0.6 \text{m}\) from the pivot, the barrier is horizontal and balanced as shown in Fig. 3.1
The man raises the barrier and the heavy weight slips to a distance of \(0.8 \text{m}\) from the pivot. This causes a problem for the man trying to lower the barrier
Describe and explain the problem this causes for the man lowering the barrier
Fig. 3.1 shows a barrier used at a car park. The beam can be raised and lowered by a man rotating it about its pivot
Describe the energy changes that take place as the ball rolls from the starting point to the stopping point
The height of the stopping point is less than the height of the starting point
Describe how the principle of conservation of energy explains the difference between the height of the stopping point and the height of the starting point
A student investigates energy changes when a ball rolls down a curved track
The student holds the ball at a starting point on the curved track, as shown in Fig. 4.1
The ball is released. It rolls down the track, up the other side to the stopping point and then back down again
State the name of the device shown in Fig. 5.1
The atmospheric pressure is equal to \(75 \text{cm}\) of mercury
Determine the pressure of the gas in the cylinder. Use information from Fig. 5.1
pressure of gas = .........\(cm\) of mercury
Fig. 5.2 shows two identical heavy stone tiles placed on soft ground. One is vertical and the other is horizontal
One of the tiles sinks into the soft ground
State and explain which tile sinks into the soft ground
Fig. 5.1 shows a device connected to a gas cylinder. The device is used to measure the pressure of the gas inside the cylinder
State the temperature indicated on the thermometer in Fig. 6.1
Explain why:
1. the bulb is made from thin glass
the tube, along which the liquid expands, is narrow
Fig. 6.1 shows a liquid-in-glass thermometer
A substance cools from \(40^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(- 20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
The substance takes 40 minutes to cool from \(40^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to its melting point of \(- 12^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). The substance then takes 20 minutes to freeze
On Fig. 6.2, sketch a temperatureâ€“time graph as the substance cools from \(40^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(- 20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
On Fig. 7.1, write the names of the radiations in the other two parts of the electromagnetic spectrum
State one use of \(\gamma \text{-rays}\)
A star emits radio waves and \(\gamma \text{-rays}\) at the same time. They all travel across the vacuum of space to the Earth's atmosphere
State whether the radio waves or the \(\gamma \text{-rays}\), if either, arrive first at the Earth's atmosphere. Give a reason for your answer
statement
reason
Both radio waves and \(\gamma \text{-rays}\) (gamma) are radiations in the electromagnetic spectrum. Fig. 7.1 shows the main regions of the electromagnetic spectrum. Most regions are labelled
Use the graph in Fig. 7.2 to determine the time between pulses
time between pulses = .........\(s\)
Determine the frequency of the pulses in Fig. 7.2
frequency = .........\(Hz\)
Fig. 7.2 shows pulses of a signal from a star
On Fig. 8.1, draw the normal where the ray meets the flat surface at X
On Fig. 8.1, label the angle of refraction. Use the letter R for the label
The student uses a semicircular glass block. State the name of **one** other piece of equipment that he needs for the investigation
He shines a ray of red light into the block, as shown in Fig. 8.1
X is the middle of the flat surface
Fig. 8.2 shows a ray of red light incident on the flat surface of the semicircular glass block
The angle of incidence is greater than the critical angle for glass
On Fig. 8.2, draw the path of the ray after it strikes the flat surface
A student uses a semicircular glass block to investigate refraction
The current in the metal wires of the circuit is a flow of particles
State the name of these particles
State the name of component X
The circuit is in a darkened room. The voltmeter reading is \(5.5\mathrm{V}\) and the ammeter reading is \(0.050\mathrm{A}\)
Calculate the resistance of the light-dependent resistor (LDR)
resistance = .........\(\Omega\)
Fig. 9.1 shows an electric circuit
The light in the room is switched on. The room becomes bright
State and explain how increasing the brightness of the light that falls on the LDR changes the current in the circuit
The electric motor has a current-carrying coil in a magnetic field. The screwdriver's manufacturer decides that the turning effect of the coil is too small
State **three** ways of increasing the turning effect of the coil
The coil in the motor can rotate in either direction
State what happens in the coil to reverse the direction of rotation

parts.label: (b)

content.text: The battery is charged using a transformer connected to an a.c. power supply
The primary voltage \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) to the transformer is \(234\mathrm{V}\) and the secondary voltage \(V_{\mathrm{s}}\) of the transformer is \(18\mathrm{V}\)
The number of turns on the primary coil \(N_{\mathrm{p}}\) is 2470 turns
Calculate the number of turns on the secondary coil \(N_{\mathrm{s}}\)

content.text: Fig. 10.1 shows an electric screwdriver which has an electric motor and a battery
The nuclide notation \(^{A}_{Z}\mathrm{X}\) describes the nucleus of an atom
Draw a line from each symbol to the correct description of the symbol
**symbol** **description**
Show that the half-life of the nuclide is 5 years
Determine the year when the activity of the sample was 10 000 counts/ s
The activity of a sample of a radioactive nuclide is measured in June of each year
In June 2004 the activity was 80 000 counts/ s
In June 2014 the activity was 20 000 counts/ s
